Results.Title: 1066 Battle of Hastings, Abbey and Battlefield
Results.Summary: Relive the battle that changed England forever.
Results.ImageAlt: Battle Abbey gatehouse, viewed from the grounds

Results.Title: Abbotsbury Abbey Remains
Results.Summary: Part of a monastic building, perhaps the abbot’s lodging, of Benedictine Abbotsbury Abbey, Henry VIII ordered its destruction during the Dissolution in 1538. St Catherine's Chapel is nearby.

Results.Title: Abbotsbury, St Catherine's Chapel
Results.Summary: Set high on a hilltop overlooking Abbotsbury Abbey, this sturdily buttressed and barrel-vaulted 14th-century chapel was built by monks as a place of pilgrimage and retreat.

Results.Title: Abingdon County Hall Museum
Results.Summary: This splendid 17th century Baroque building housed a courtroom for assizes, raised on arches over a market space. It now houses the Abingdon Museum.

Results.Title: Acton Burnell Castle
Results.Summary: Twice the home of parliaments, this red sandstone shell of a semi-fortified tower house was built between 1284-93 by Bishop Burnell, Edward I's Lord Chancellor.
Results.ImageAlt: Aerial view of Acton Burnell Castle ruins alongside 13th century medieval St Mary's Church set amongst a rich planting of trees

Results.Title: Aldborough Roman Site
Results.Summary: Roman remains in a Victorian arboretum
Results.ImageAlt: Detail of a Roman mosaic at Aldborough Roman Site

Results.Title: Alexander Keiller Museum, Avebury
Results.Summary: The Stables Gallery houses one of the most important prehistoric archaeological collections in Britain, including many artefacts from the World Heritage Sites. Find out about Avebury stone circle.
Results.ImageAlt: Aerial view of Avebury showing the stone circle, church and neighbouring Alexander Keiller Museum

Results.Title: Ambleside Roman Fort
Results.Summary: The well-marked remains of a 2nd-century fort with large granaries, built under Hadrian's rule to guard the Roman road from Brougham to Ravenglass and act as a supply base.

Results.Title: Apethorpe Palace
Results.Summary: A stately palace with one of the country's most complete Jacobean interiors.
Results.ImageAlt: South facing facade of Jacobean Apethorpe Palace in the sunshine

Results.Title: Appuldurcombe House
Results.Summary: The shell of Appuldurcombe, once the grandest house on the Isle of Wight and still an important example of English baroque Architecture stands in 'Capability' Brown-designed grounds.

Results.Title: Apsley House
Results.Summary: Dazzling interiors, glittering treasures and fabulous art collections
Results.ImageAlt: The rear exterior of Apsley House

Results.Title: Arbor Low Stone Circle and Gib Hill Barrow
Results.Summary: The region's most important prehistoric site, Arbor Low is a Neolithic henge monument atmospherically set in high moorland. A circle of some 50 white limestone slabs within an earthen bank and ditch.

Results.Title: Arthur's Stone
Results.Summary: An atmospheric Neolithic burial chamber, made of great stone slabs in the hills above Herefordshire's Golden Valley.

Results.Title: Ashby de la Zouch Castle
Results.Summary: Medieval status symbol and Civil War stronghold
Results.ImageAlt: The ruins of Ashby de la Zouche Castle

Results.Title: Auckland Castle Deer House
Results.Summary: A charming Gothic Revival 'eyecatcher' built in 1760 in the park of the Bishops of Durham. It provided deer with shelter and food, and had grounds for picnics and rooms for enjoying the view.

Results.Title: Audley End House and Gardens
Results.Summary: Explore an English country house upstairs and downstairs, inside and out.
Results.ImageAlt: Daffodils growing outside Audley End House

Results.Title: Avebury
Results.Summary: With its huge circular bank and ditch and inner circle of great standing stones, covering an area of over 28 acres, Avebury forms one of the most impressive prehistoric sites in Britain.
Results.ImageAlt: Aerial view of Avebury showing the stone circle, church and neighbouring Alexander Keiller Museum

Results.Title: Aydon Castle
Results.Summary: Charming manor house-castle tucked away in the woods.
Results.ImageAlt: Aerial view of the substantial remains of Aydon Castle perched on the edge of scarp above Cor Burn

Results.Title: Baconsthorpe Castle
Results.Summary: Visit the extensive ruins of Baconsthorpe Castle, a moated and fortified 15th century manor house, that are a testament to the rise and fall of a prominent Norfolk family, the Heydons.

Results.Title: Ballowall Barrow
Results.Summary: In a spectacular cliff-edge position, this unique Bronze Age tomb had a long and complex history as a sacred site. Seen as excavated in 1878 by Cornish antiquarian William Borlase.

Results.Title: Banks East Turret - Hadrian's Wall
Results.Summary: Imposing and well-preserved turret with adjoining stretches of Hadrian's Wall.

Results.Title: Bant's Carn Burial Chamber and Halangy Down Ancient Village
Results.Summary:
The remains of an ancient Iron Age village in a wonderfully scenic
 location.On the hill above stands a Bronze Age burial mound with
 entrance passage and inner chamber.

Results.Title: Barnard Castle
Results.Summary: An imposing baronial fortress set high above the Tees Gorge.

Results.Title: Bayard's Cove Fort
Results.Summary: Picturesquely sited on the quayside at Dartmouth, this Tudor artillery fort once contained heavy guns to protect the prosperous harbour town from attack.

Results.Title: Bayham Old Abbey
Results.Summary: Bayham Abbey makes a fascinating day out on the Kent Sussex border. The impressive ruins include much of the 13th to 15th-century church, the chapter house, and a picturesque 14th-century gatehouse.

Results.Title: Beeston Castle and Woodland Park
Results.Summary: Amazing views across eight counties, woodland walks, and a strikingly recreated Bronze Age roundhouse.
Results.ImageAlt: Visitors crossing the bridge leading into Beeston Castle keep

Results.Title: Belas Knap Long Barrow
Results.Summary: A particularly fine example of a Neolithic long barrow of c.3800 BC, featuring a false entrance and side chambers. During excavations in the 1860s, the remains of 31 people were found in the chambers.

Results.Title: Belsay Hall, Castle and Gardens
Results.Summary: Belsay is big, beautiful and bursting with things to see and do.
Results.ImageAlt: Belsay Hall

Results.Title: Benwell Roman Temple - Hadrian's Wall
Results.Summary: The remains of a small temple to the native god 'Antenociticus', in the 'vicus' (civilian settlement) which stood outside Benwell fort.

Results.Title: Benwell Vallum Crossing
Results.Summary: A stone-built causeway, where the road from the south crossed the Vallum earthwork on its way to Benwell fort.

Results.Title: Berkhamsted Castle
Results.Summary: Visit the substantial remains of a strong and important motte and bailey castle dating from the 11th to 13th centuries, with surrounding walls, ditches and earthworks.

Results.Title: Berney Arms Windmill
Results.Summary: Visit one of Norfolk's best and largest extant marsh mills, built to grind a constituent of cement and in use until 1948, finally pumping water to drain surrounding marshland.

Results.Title: Berry Pomeroy Castle
Results.Summary: The perfect romantic ruin, tucked away in woodland.
Results.ImageAlt: The defensive gatehouse of Berry Pomeroy Castle

Results.Title: Berwick-upon-Tweed Barracks and Main Guard
Results.Summary: ...Watch this space...

Results.Title: Berwick-upon-Tweed Castle and Ramparts
Results.Summary: The remains of a medieval castle crucial to Anglo-Scottish warfare.

Results.Title: Bessie Surtees House
Results.Summary: Two magnificent five-storey Newcastle merchants’ houses, dating from the mid-17th century.

Results.Title: Binham Market Cross
Results.Summary: The tall shaft of a 15th century cross, on the site of an annual fair held from the 1100s until the 1950s.

Results.Title: Binham Priory
Results.Summary: Among the most complete and impressive monastic ruins in Norfolk of a Benedictine priory with a well-documented history.

Results.Title: Birdoswald Roman Fort - Hadrian's Wall
Results.Summary: Enjoy an adventure in Roman Britain with fantastic defences and displays.
Results.ImageAlt: An aerial view of Birdoswald Roman Fort

Results.Title: Bishop's Waltham Palace
Results.Summary: The ruins of a medieval palace (together with later additions) used by the Bishops and senior clergy of Winchester as they travelled through their diocese.

Results.Title: Black Carts Turret - Hadrian's Wall
Results.Summary: A 460-metre (1,509-foot) length of Hadrian's Wall including one turret. Please note: It is not possible for visitors to park here.

Results.Title: Black Middens Bastle House
Results.Summary: A fortified farmhouse with thick stone walls, of a type distinctive to the troubled 16th-century Anglo-Scottish borders. The living quarters were only accessible at first floor level.

Results.Title: Blackbury Camp
Results.Summary: An Iron Age hillfort in Devon with impressive ramparts, now surrounded by woodland.

Results.Title: Blackfriars
Results.Summary: One of the most complete surviving Dominican friaries in England, later converted into a Tudor house and cloth factory. Notable features include the church and fine scissor-braced dormitory roof.

Results.Title: Blakeney Guildhall
Results.Summary: The remains of the house of a prosperous Blakeney merchant, with a fine 15th century brick-vaulted undercroft. Later the guildhall of Blakeney’s guild of fish merchants.

Results.Title: Bolingbroke Castle
Results.Summary: The remains of a 13th-century hexagonal castle, birthplace in 1367 of the future King Henry IV, with adjacent earthworks. Besieged and taken by Cromwell's Parliamentarians in 1643.

Results.Title: Bolsover Castle
Results.Summary: A Stuart showpiece with lavish rooms and amazing views
Results.ImageAlt: The elaborate entrance to Bolsover Castle

Results.Title: Bolsover Cundy House
Results.Summary: This charming cottage-like 17th-century conduit house, with vaulted stone-slab roof, once supplied water to Bolsover Castle.

Results.Title: Boscobel House and The Royal Oak
Results.Summary: A royal great escape and a great day out.
Results.ImageAlt: Image: a couple walk in front of the Royal Oak

Results.Title: Bow Bridge
Results.Summary: This narrow 15th-century stone bridge across Mill Beck carried an old packhorse route to nearby Furness Abbey.

Results.Title: Bowes Castle
Results.Summary: The impressive ruins of Henry II's 12th-century keep, on the site of a Roman fort guarding the approach to strategic Stainmore Pass over the Pennines.

Results.Title: Boxgrove Priory
Results.Summary: The guest house and other remains of a Benedictine priory: much of the fine 12th to 14th century monastic church survives as the parish church.

Results.Title: Bradford-on-Avon Tithe Barn
Results.Summary: A spectacular 14th century monastic stone barn, 51 metres (168 feet) long, with an amazing timber cruck roof. Originally a part of the medieval farmstead belonging to Shaftesbury Abbey.

Results.Title: Bramber Castle
Results.Summary: The remains of a Norman castle on the banks of the River Adur, founded by William de Braose soon after the Norman Conquest.

Results.Title: Bratton Camp and White Horse
Results.Summary: Below an Iron Age hillfort stands the Westbury White Horse. Cut into the hillside in 1778, it replaced an older horse, possibly commemorating King Alfred's nearby victory over the Vikings.

Results.Title: Brinkburn Priory
Results.Summary: A complete monastic church in an enchanting setting
Results.ImageAlt: Brinkburn church and manor house

Results.Title: Brodsworth Hall and Gardens
Results.Summary: Victorian country house frozen in time and award-winning gardens
Results.ImageAlt: Brodsworth Hall

Results.Title: Brough Castle
Results.Summary: Starkly impressive Brough Castle stands on a ridge commanding strategic Stainmore Pass, on the site of a Roman fort.

Results.Title: Brougham Castle
Results.Summary: Imposing riverside castle ruins
Results.ImageAlt: A bridge over the river with Brougham Castle in the background

Results.Title: Brunton Turret - Hadrian's Wall
Results.Summary: Wall section and a surviving piece of turret 2 1/2 metres (8.2 feet) high, built by men of the Twentieth Legion.

Results.Title: Buildwas Abbey
Results.Summary: The impressive ruins of this Cistercian abbey have an idyllic setting near the River Severn. Unaltered 12th century church and beautiful vaulted chapter house with tiled floor.

Results.Title: Burgh Castle Roman Fort
Results.Summary: The imposing stone walls, with added towers for catapults, of a Roman 3rd century ‘Saxon Shore’ fort. Enjoy panoramic views over Breydon Water, into which the fourth wall long since collapsed.

Results.Title: Burton Agnes Manor House
Results.Summary: A medieval manor house interior, with a rare and well preserved Norman undercroft and a 15th-century roof, all encased in brick during the 17th and 18th centuries.

Results.Title: Bury St Edmunds Abbey
Results.Summary: The extensive remains of one of the wealthiest and most powerful Benedictine monasteries in England, shrine of St Edmund.

Results.Title: Bushmead Priory
Results.Summary: A complete and unusually well-preserved 13th-century monk’s dining hall.
Results.ImageAlt: Exterior photo of Bushmead Priory surrounded by trees on a sunny day

Results.Title: Byland Abbey
Results.Summary: Once one of the greatest monasteries in England, Byland Abbey inspired the design of church buildings throughout North.

Results.Title: Caister Roman Fort
Results.Summary: The partial excavated remains of a Roman ‘Saxon Shore’ fort, including wall and ditch sections and building foundations.

Results.Title: Calshot Castle
Results.Summary: This picturesque castle set in Calshot, a coastal village in Southampton, Hampshire, England. This beautiful village provides a perfect relaxing family day out by the coast.

Results.Title: Camber Castle
Results.Summary: Built by Henry VIII, Camber Castle lies between Rye and Winchelsea. The ruin of an unaltered artillery fort designed to guard the port of Rye.

Results.Title: Cantlop Bridge
Results.Summary: Built in 1813, this innovative, single-span, cast-iron road bridge over the Cound Brook was possibly designed and certainly approved by the great engineer Thomas Telford.

Results.Title: Carisbrooke Castle
Results.Summary: Defender of the Isle of Wight for more than a thousand years
Results.ImageAlt: The Norman Keep at Carisbrooke Castle

Results.Title: Carlisle Castle
Results.Summary: Crucial border fortress with a long and turbulent history
Results.ImageAlt: The imposing walls of Carlisle Castle

Results.Title: Carn Euny Ancient Village
Results.Summary: Among the preserved ancient villages in the South West, occupied from the Iron Age until late Roman times. It includes the foundations of stone houses, and an intriguing underground passage.

Results.Title: Carrawburgh Roman Fort and Temple of Mithras - Hadrian's Wall
Results.Summary: One of 16 forts along Hadrian’s Wall, Carrawburgh once housed about 500 soldiers responsible for defending the frontier. Nearby stands a fascinating temple to the god Mithras, with facsimiles of altars found during excavation.

Results.Title: Castle Acre Castle and Bailey Gate
Results.Summary: The delightful village of Castle Acre boasts an extraordinary wealth of history and is a very rare and complete survival of a Norman planned settlement.

Results.Title: Castle Acre: Castle Acre Priory
Results.Summary: Explore East Anglia’s biggest and best-preserved monastic ruins
Results.ImageAlt: The ruins of Castle Acre Priory

Results.Title: Castle Rising Castle
Results.Summary: One of the largest, best preserved and most lavishly decorated keeps in England, surrounded by 20 acres of mighty earthworks.

Results.Title: Castlerigg Stone Circle
Results.Summary: Castlerigg is perhaps the most atmospheric and dramatically sited of all British stone circles, with panoramic views and the mountains of Helvellyn and High Seat as a backdrop.

Results.Title: Cawfields Roman Wall - Hadrian's Wall
Results.Summary: A fine stretch of Hadrian's Wall on a steep slope, with turrets and an impressive milecastle, probably built by the Second Legion.

Results.Title: Chapter House and Pyx Chamber
Results.Summary: Built by the royal masons in 1250, the Chapter House of Westminster Abbey was originally used in the 13th century by Benedictine monks for their daily meetings.

Results.Title: Chester Castle: Agricola Tower and Castle Walls
Results.Summary: The original gateway to Chester Castle, this 12th-century tower houses a chapel with exceptionally fine wall-paintings of c. 1220, rediscovered in the 1980s.

Results.Title: Chester Roman Amphitheatre
Results.Summary: The largest Roman amphitheatre in Britain, used for entertainment and military training by the 20th Legion, based at the fortress of 'Deva' (Chester).

Results.Title: Chesters Bridge Abutment - Hadrian's Wall
Results.Summary: Close to Chesters Roman Fort are the remains of a bridge which carried Hadrian's Wall across the North Tyne. Visible on both river banks, they are most impressive on the eastern side.

Results.Title: Chesters Roman Fort and Museum - Hadrian's Wall
Results.Summary: Riverside Roman fort and bath house with period-piece museum
Results.ImageAlt: The ruins of Chesters Roman Fort

Results.Title: Chichele College
Results.Summary: The gatehouse, chapel and other remains of a communal residence for priests serving the parish church, founded by locally-born Archbishop Chichele before 1425. Regularly used for events, and art and heritage exhibitions.

Results.Title: Chisbury Chapel
Results.Summary: This pretty thatched and flintwalled 13th century chapel survived after the Reformation in 1547 by being used as a barn as part of Chisbury Farm.

Results.Title: Chiswick House and Gardens
Results.Summary: Chiswick House is a glorious example of 18th-century British architecture. The 3rd Earl of Burlington, who designed this elegant villa, drew inspiration from his Grand Tours of Italy.

Results.Title: Christchurch Castle and Norman House
Results.Summary: The castle remains include parts of the keep and the 12th century riverside chamber block or Norman House, a very early example of domestic architecture including a rare Norman chimney.

Results.Title: Chysauster Ancient Village
Results.Summary: A long-lost village in beautiful Cornish countryside

Results.Title: Cirencester Amphitheatre
Results.Summary: The earthwork remains of one of the largest Roman amphitheatres in Britain, built in the early 2nd century to serve the important city of Corinium, now Cirencester.

Results.Title: Cleeve Abbey
Results.Summary: A vivid insight into monastic life
Results.ImageAlt: A rugged tree outside the entrance-arch leading to Cleeve Abbey

Results.Title: Clifford's Tower, York
Results.Summary: Unrivalled views and immersive story telling at the heart of the city
Results.ImageAlt: An aerial view of Clifford's Tower

Results.Title: Clifton Hall
Results.Summary: This 15th-century tower, sole surviving part of the manor house of the Wybergh family, was plundered by Jacobites in 1745 before the Battle of Clifton Moor, the last battle fought on English soil.

Results.Title: Clun Castle
Results.Summary: 11th century Welsh Border castle with dramatic riverside location and extensive earthworks built to proclaim Norman dominance. Tall 13th century keep is unusually set on the side of its mound.

Results.Title: Colchester, St Botolph's Priory
Results.Summary: The remains of one of the first Augustinian priories in England, founded in c.1100 and an impressive example of early Norman architecture.

Results.Title: Conisbrough Castle
Results.Summary: Power and projections in a unique cylindrical keep
Results.ImageAlt: Conisbrough Castle keep

Results.Title: Coombe Conduit
Results.Summary: Coombe Conduit is made up of two small Tudor buildings connected by an underground passage.Water was once supplied to Hampton Court Palace via this tunnel.

Results.Title: Corbridge Roman Town - Hadrian's Wall
Results.Summary: Walk along a Roman high street, and see the famous Corbridge Hoard.
Results.ImageAlt: Ruins of Corbridge Roman Town

Results.Title: Countess Pillar, Brougham
Results.Summary: A monument erected in 1656 by Lady Anne Clifford of nearby Brougham Castle, to commemorate her final parting here from her mother.

Results.Title: Cow Tower, Norwich
Results.Summary: One of the earliest purpose-built artillery blockhouses in England, this brick tower was built in c.1398-9 to command a strategic point in Norwich’s city defence.

Results.Title: Creake Abbey
Results.Summary: The ruined church of an Augustinian abbey, reduced in size after fire and plague.

Results.Title: Cromwell's Castle
Results.Summary: The castle stands guarding the lovely anchorage between Bryher and Tresco and is one of the few surviving Cromwellian fortifications in Britain.

Results.Title: Croxden Abbey
Results.Summary: The impressive remains of an abbey of Cistercian 'white monks', including towering fragments of its 13th-century church, infirmary and 14th-century abbot's lodging.

Results.Title: Dartmouth Castle
Results.Summary: A stunning waterfront fortress
Results.ImageAlt: A view across the bay from the top of Dartmouth Castle

Results.Title: Daw's Castle
Results.Summary: Daw's Castle is a clifftop fortress, which was founded by King Alfred to defend the people of Watchet against Viking attacks.

Results.Title: De Grey Mausoleum, Flitton
Results.Summary: Among the largest sepulchral chapels attached to any English church, this cruciform mausoleum houses a remarkable sequence of 17 sculpted and effigied monuments.

Results.Title: Deal Castle
Results.Summary: Devilish defences at one of Henry VIII’s finest artillery forts
Results.ImageAlt: The entrance of Deal Castle

Results.Title: Deddington Castle
Results.Summary: Extensive earthworks marking the site of an 11th century motte and bailey castle.

Results.Title: Denny Abbey and the Farmland Museum
Results.Summary: Denny Abbey has a unique and fascinating history still traceable in the building and interpreted for visitors by graphic panels.

Results.Title: Denton Hall Turret - Hadrian's Wall
Results.Summary: The foundations of a turret and a 65-metre (213 foot) length of Wall, along with another 60-metre length of Wall further west.

Results.Title: Derwentcote Steel Furnace
Results.Summary: Built in the 1720s, Derwentcote is the earliest and most complete steel-making furnace in Britain. It produced high-grade steel for springs and cutting tools.

Results.Title: Donnington Castle
Results.Summary: The striking twin-towered 14th-century gatehouse of this castle, later the focus of a Civil War siege and battle, survives amid impressive earthworks.
Results.ImageAlt: Donnington Castle

Results.Title: Dover Castle
Results.Summary: High atop the iconic White Cliffs of Dover sits the most iconic of all English fortresses. From the mighty medieval keep to the labyrinth of secret wartime tunnels below, a family day out at Dover towers above all others.

Results.Title: Dunstanburgh Castle
Results.Summary: Dramatic ruins on the wild Northumberland coast
Results.ImageAlt: The ruins of Dunstanburgh Castle

Results.Title: Dunster Butter Cross
Results.Summary: Transplanted stump of a medieval stone cross that was once a meeting place for people to bring and sell their own butter. Nearby attractions include Cleeve Abbey.

Results.Title: Dunster Gallox Bridge
Results.Summary: This ancient stone bridge - originally 'gallows bridge' - once carried packhorses bringing fleeces to Dunster market and is evidence of Dunster's once important role in the wool trade.

Results.Title: Dunster, Yarn Market
Results.Summary: Fine 17th century timber-framed octagonal market hall that is a monument to Dunster's once-flourishing cloth trade.

Results.Title: Dupath Well
Results.Summary: This charming well-house of around 1500 stands over an ancient spring, believed to cure whooping cough.

Results.Title: Duxford Chapel
Results.Summary: A modest but complete and attractive 14th-century chantry chapel, perhaps originally a hospital.

Results.Title: Dymchurch Martello Tower
Results.Summary: This is one of a chain of ingeniously designed artillery towers built around the south and east coasts of England from 1805 to protect against the threat of invasion by Napoleon.

Results.Title: Easby Abbey
Results.Summary: In a beautiful setting by the River Swale, Easby can be reached via a pleasant walk from Richmond Castle.

Results.Title: Edlingham Castle
Results.Summary: The riverside ruins, principally the solar tower, of a manor house progressively fortified against the Scots during the 14th century.

Results.Title: Edvin Loach Old Church
Results.Summary: The ruins of an 11th century and later church built within the earthworks of a Norman motte and bailey castle, with a Victorian church nearby. The site of hundreds of years of worship.

Results.Title: Egglestone Abbey
Results.Summary: The charming ruins of a small monastery of Premonstratensian 'white canons', picturesquely set above a bend in the River Tees near Barnard Castle.

Results.Title: Eleanor Cross, Geddington
Results.Summary: In 1290 Eleanor of Castile, the beloved wife of Edward I and mother of his 14 children, died at Harby in Nottinghamshire.

Results.Title: Eltham Palace and Gardens
Results.Summary: Millionaire life in an art deco mansion
Results.ImageAlt: Eltham Palace viewed from across the moat

Results.Title: Etal Castle
Results.Summary: Etal was built in the mid 14th century by Robert Manners as a defence against Scots raiders, in a strategic position by a ford over the river Till.

Results.Title: Eynsford Castle
Results.Summary: The substantial stone walls of a very early Norman 'enclosure castle', begun c.1085-7 and unusually little altered by later building works. This rare survival stands in an attractive village setting.

Results.Title: Farleigh Hungerford Castle
Results.Summary: Mysterious tales and a creepy chapel crypt

Results.Title: Farnham Castle Keep
Results.Summary: The impressive motte and shell keep of Farnham Castle, Surrey, founded in 1138 by Bishop Henry of Blois. An enjoyable day out within travelling distance of London.

Results.Title: Faversham Stone Chapel (Our Lady of Elverton)
Results.Summary: The ruins of the small Anglo-Saxon and medieval chapel of Stone-next-Faversham.

Results.Title: Fiddleford Manor
Results.Summary: The principal parts of a small stone manor house, probably begun about 1370 for William Latimer, Sheriff of Somerset and Dorset. The hall and solar chamber display outstandingly fine timber roofs.

Results.Title: Finchale Priory
Results.Summary: The very extensive remains of a 13th-century priory, founded on the site of a retired pirate's hermitage. Part of it later served as a holiday retreat for the monks of Durham Cathedral.

Results.Title: Flowerdown Barrows
Results.Summary: Three Bronze Age burial mounds, once part of a much larger 'barrow cemetery', including two bowl barrows, and the largest and finest disc barrow in Hampshire.

Results.Title: Fort Brockhurst
Results.Summary: One of a number of forts built in the 1850s and 1860s to protect Portsmouth and its harbour against a French invasion. Largely unaltered, the parade ground, gun ramps and moated keep can be viewed.

Results.Title: Framlingham Castle
Results.Summary: One of medieval England’s finest baronial fortresses, with plenty to see and do.

Results.Title: Furness Abbey
Results.Summary: The North West’s most majestic abbey ruins, now with a recreated monks’ eye view.
Results.ImageAlt: The ruins of Furness Abbey

Results.Title: Gainsborough Old Hall
Results.Summary: Discover one of England’s biggest – yet least known – medieval manor houses
Results.ImageAlt: An aerial view of Gainsborough old Hall

Results.Title: Gainsthorpe Medieval Village
Results.Summary: A deserted medieval village, one of the best-preserved examples in England, clearly visible as a complex of grassy humps and bumps.

Results.Title: Garrison Walls
Results.Summary: You can enjoy a two-hour walk alongside the ramparts of these defensive walls and earthworks, dating from the 16th to 18th centuries.

Results.Title: Gisborough Priory
Results.Summary: The ruins of an Augustinian priory founded by the Bruce family, afterwards Kings of Scotland. They are dominated by the dramatic skeleton of the 14th-century church's east end.

Results.Title: Glastonbury Tribunal
Results.Summary: Fine, late 15th century stone townhouse, early Tudor façade and panelled interiors. Home to Glastonbury Lake Village Exhibition: discover life 2000 years ago when much of Somerset consisted of marshy sea.

Results.Title: Goodrich Castle
Results.Summary: Medieval life in a picturesque and powerful stronghold

Results.Title: Goodshaw Chapel
Results.Summary: English Heritage's only Nonconformist place of worship, this atmospheric Baptist chapel displays a complete set of box-pews, galleries and pulpit dating from c. 1742 to 1809.

Results.Title: Great Witcombe Roman Villa
Results.Summary: The remains of a large and luxurious villa built about AD 250, with a bathhouse complex, perhaps the shrine of a water spirit, and mosaics.

Results.Title: Great Yarmouth Row Houses and Greyfriars' Cloisters
Results.Summary: Vividly presented evocations of life in a fishing port, open again after conservation
Results.ImageAlt: Photo of the outside of a red-brick Row House in Great Yarmouth

Results.Title: Greyfriars
Results.Summary: Substantial remains of an early Tudor friary church of Franciscan 'grey friars' founded in 1231.

Results.Title: Grime's Graves - Prehistoric Flint Mine
Results.Summary: Visit Grime’s Graves and explore Britain’s only open Neolithic flint mine.

Results.Title: Grimspound
Results.Summary: The best known of many Dartmoor prehistoric settlements, Grimspound dates from the late Bronze Age. The remains of 24 stone houses survive within a massive boundary wall.

Results.Title: Hadleigh Castle
Results.Summary: The romantic ruins of a royal castle overlooking the Essex marshes. Hadleigh was begun in about 1215 by Hubert de Burgh, but extensively refortified by Edward III during the Hundred Years War.

Results.Title: Hadrian's Wall
Results.Summary: Hadrian’s Wall was the north-west frontier of the Roman empire for nearly 300 years. At 73 miles it marches across northern Britain from sea to sea. The most famous of all the frontiers of the Roman empire, Hadrian’s Wall was made a World Heritage Site in 1987.

Results.Title: Hailes Abbey
Results.Summary: Home of the Holy Blood
Results.ImageAlt: The ruins of Hailes Abbey

Results.Title: Halesowen Abbey
Results.Summary: Remains of abbey founded by King John in the 13th century.

Results.Title: Halliggye Fogou
Results.Summary: Roofed and walled in stone, this complex of passages is the largest and best-preserved of several mysterious underground tunnels associated with Cornish Iron Age settlements.
Results.ImageAlt: View looking along the straight passage of Halliggye Fogou

Results.Title: Hardknott Roman Fort
Results.Summary: This remote and dramatically sited fort was founded under Hadrian's rule in the 2nd century. Well-marked remains include the headquarters building, commandant's house and bath house.

Results.Title: Hardwick Old Hall and Hardwick Hall
Results.Summary: Two great Elizabethan mansions, side by side.
Results.ImageAlt: An aerial view of Hardwick Old Hall

Results.Title: Hare Hill - Hadrian's Wall
Results.Summary: A short length of Wall, still standing 2.7 metres (8.8 feet) high.

Results.Title: Harmondsworth Barn
Results.Summary: This Grade I listed oak-framed medieval barn ranks alongside the Houses of Parliament, Westminster Abbey and Buckingham Palace for its exceptional architectural and historic interest.

Results.Title: Harrows Scar Milecastle and Wall - Hadrian's Wall
Results.Summary: A mile-long section of the Wall, rebuilt in stone later in Hadrian's reign. It is linked to Birdoswald Roman Fort.

Results.Title: Harry's Walls
Results.Summary: An unfinished artillery fort, built above St Mary's Pool harbour in 1552-53.

Results.Title: Hatfield Earthworks (Marden Henge)
Results.Summary: The earthworks of a Neolithic henge and monumental mound, by a loop in the River Avon. Recent archaeological find of building equivalent to a priest’s quarters.

Results.Title: Haughmond Abbey
Results.Summary: Extensive remains of Augustinian abbey, including abbots' quarters, refectory & cloister. Chapter house frontage with 12th & 14th century carving & statuary, timber roof c.1500. Displays, picnic area.

Results.Title: Heddon on the Wall  Hadrian's Wall
Results.Summary: A consolidated stretch of Wall, up to 2 metres (6.6 feet) thick in places.

Results.Title: Helmsley Archaeology Store
Results.Summary: Helmsley Archaeology Store holds the extensive archaeological collections and paper based archives from English Heritage guardianship sites from the North of England including the counties of Northumberland, County Durham, Cumbria, Lancashire, Yorkshire, North Lincolnshire, Cheshire.

Results.Title: Helmsley Castle
Results.Summary: Explore the story of a great castle across nine centuries
Results.ImageAlt: The exterior of Helmsley Castle

Results.Title: Hill Hall
Results.Summary: This fine Elizabethan mansion features some of the earliest external Renaissance architectural detail in the country.
Results.ImageAlt: Exterior photo of Hill Hall on a sunny day

Results.Title: Hob Hurst's House
Results.Summary: A square prehistoric burial mound with an earthwork ditch and outer bank. Named after a local goblin.

Results.Title: Home of Charles Darwin - Down House
Results.Summary: The great scientist’s country-house home and ‘outdoor laboratory’
Results.ImageAlt: The exterior of Down House

Results.Title: Horne's Place Chapel
Results.Summary: A rare survival of a fine domestic chapel, built for William Horne in 1366 and attached to his timber-framed manor house, which was attacked during the Peasants' Revolt of 1381.

Results.Title: Houghton House
Results.Summary: Houghton House today is the shell of a 17th century mansion commanding magnificent views, reputedly the inspiration for the ‘House Beautiful’ in John Bunyan’s Pilgrim’s Progress.

Results.Title: Hound Tor Deserted Medieval Village
Results.Summary: The remains of four 13th century stone farmsteads, on land originally farmed in the Bronze Age. This isolated Dartmoor hamlet was probably abandoned in the early 15th century.

Results.Title: Housesteads Roman Fort - Hadrian's Wall
Results.Summary: Britain’s most complete Roman fort, in a spectacular landscape.
Results.ImageAlt: Remains of underfloor heating at Housesteads Roman Fort

Results.Title: Howden Minster
Results.Summary: The elaborately decorated ruins of a 14th-century chancel and chapter house (viewable only from the outside), attached to the still operational cathedral-like minster church.

Results.Title: Hurlers Stone Circles
Results.Summary: Three fine late Neolithic or early Bronze Age stone circles arranged in a line, a grouping unique in England.

Results.Title: Hurst Castle
Results.Summary: Hurst Castle provides a remote escape by the sea with plenty of things to do and see! Built by Henry VIII; one of the most advanced artillery fortresses in England.

Results.Title: Hylton Castle
Results.Summary: The distinctive and highly decorative gatehouse-tower of a castle built by the wealthy Sir William Hylton, shortly before 1400. Originally containing four floors of self-contained family.

Results.Title: Innisidgen Lower and Upper Burial Chambers
Results.Summary: Two Bronze Age communal burial cairns of Scillonian type, with fine views. The upper cairn is the best preserved on the islands.

Results.Title: Iron Bridge
Results.Summary: The world’s first iron bridge was erected over the River Severn here in 1779 by Abraham Darby III. Costing over £6000, the bridge was cast in his Coalbrookdale foundry, using 378 tons of iron.
Results.ImageAlt: The newly repainted Iron Bridge

Results.Title: Isleham Priory Church
Results.Summary: Isleham Priory Church is the best example in England of a small Norman Benedictine priory church, surviving in a surprisingly unaltered state despite later conversion into a barn.

Results.Title: JW Evans Silver Factory
Results.Summary: A treasure trove of industry frozen in time.
Results.ImageAlt: A selection of fly presses in the workshop at J.W. Evans Silver Factory

Results.Title: Jewel Tower
Results.Summary: A hidden treasury in the heart of London

Results.Title: Jewry Wall
Results.Summary: A length of Roman bath-house wall over 9 metres (30 feet) high, near a museum displaying the archaeology of Leicester and its region.

Results.Title: Jordan Hill Roman Temple
Results.Summary: The foundations of a 4th century Romano-Celtic temple with fine coastal views.

Results.Title: Kenilworth Castle and Elizabethan Garden
Results.Summary: Medieval fortress turned showstopper Elizabethan palace
Results.ImageAlt: The ruins of Kenilworth Castle

Results.Title: Kenwood
Results.Summary: This outstanding house beside Hampstead Heath was remodelled by Robert Adam between 1764 and 1779. He transformed the original brick building into a majestic villa for the great judge, Lord Mansfield.

Results.Title: King Arthur's Round Table
Results.Summary: A Neolithic earthwork henge, dating from c. 2000 BC, but much later believed to be King Arthur's jousting arena. Mayburgh Henge is adjacent.

Results.Title: King Charles's Castle
Results.Summary: The ruins of a mid 16th century coastal artillery fort, later garrisoned - hence the name - by Civil War Royalists.

Results.Title: King Doniert's Stone
Results.Summary: Two richly carved pieces of a 9th century 'Celtic' cross, with an inscription commemorating Dumgarth, British King of Dumnonia, who drowned in c. AD 875.

Results.Title: King James's and Landport Gates, Portsmouth
Results.Summary: Two ornamental gateways, once part of Portsmouth's defences. King James's Gate (of 1687) has been moved, but Landport Gate (1760), remains in it's original position.

Results.Title: Kingston Russell Stone Circle
Results.Summary: A late Neolithic or early Bronze Age circle of 18 fallen stones, on a hilltop overlooking Abbotsbury and the sea.

Results.Title: Kingswood Abbey Gatehouse
Results.Summary: This 16th century gatehouse, one of the latest monastic buildings in England, displays a richly sculpted mullioned window. It is the sole survivor of this Cistercian abbey.

Results.Title: Kirby Hall
Results.Summary: Trace the rise and fall of a great Elizabethan and Stuart mansion.

Results.Title: Kirby Muxloe Castle
Results.Summary: The unfinished showpiece mansion of a royal favourite – and royal victim

Results.Title: Kirkham House, Paignton
Results.Summary: This late medieval stone house, afterwards split into three cottages was restored in the 1960s.

Results.Title: Kirkham Priory
Results.Summary: Idyllic riverside ruins with a surprising recent history

Results.Title: Kit's Coty House and Little Kit's Coty House
Results.Summary: The remains of two megalithic 'dolmen' burial chambers. Impressive Kit's Coty has three uprights and a massive capstone: Little Kit's Coty, alias the Countless Stones, is now a jumble of sarsens.

Results.Title: Knights Templar Church, Dover
Results.Summary: The foundations of a small medieval church, traditionally said to have been the site of King John's submission to the Papal Legate in 1213.

Results.Title: Knowlton Church and Earthworks
Results.Summary: The siting of this ruined medieval church at the centre of a Neolithic ritual henge earthwork symbolises the transition from pagan to Christian worship and creates an atmospheric scene.

Results.Title: Landguard Fort
Results.Summary: Landguard Fort is the site of the last opposed seaborne invasion of England in 1667 and the first land battle of the Royal Marines.

Results.Title: Lanercost Priory
Results.Summary: An impressive and now-tranquil priory, once in the Anglo-Scottish firing line.
Results.ImageAlt: The exterior of Lanercost Priory

Results.Title: Langley Chapel
Results.Summary: A small chapel tranquilly set all alone in charming countryside. Its atmospheric interior contains a perfect set of 17th-century timber furnishings, including a musicians' pew.

Results.Title: Launceston Castle
Results.Summary: Stunning views from Cornwall’s most important medieval fortress
Results.ImageAlt: Launceston Castle with flowers in the foreground

Results.Title: Leahill Turret and Piper Sike Turret - Hadrian's Wall
Results.Summary: Turrets west of Birdoswald: Piper Sike has a cooking-hearth.

Results.Title: Leigh Court Barn
Results.Summary: An outstanding display of English medieval carpentry, this mighty timber-framed barn is the largest cruck structure in Britain.

Results.Title: Leiston Abbey
Results.Summary: The mainly 14th century remains of an abbey of Premonstratensian canons. Among Suffolk’s most impressive monastic ruins, with some spectacular architectural features.

Results.Title: Lexden Earthworks and Bluebottle Grove
Results.Summary: The banks and ditches of a series of late Iron Age defences protecting the western side of Camulodunum – pre-Roman Colchester.

Results.Title: Lilleshall Abbey
Results.Summary: Extensive ruins of an Augustinian abbey, later a Civil War stronghold, in a deeply rural setting.

Results.Title: Lincoln Medieval Bishops' Palace
Results.Summary: See how we’ve safeguarded the home of Lincoln’s medieval bishops.
Results.ImageAlt: A couple exploire Lincoln Medieval Bishop's Palace

Results.Title: Lindisfarne Priory
Results.Summary: England’s holy island.

Results.Title: Lindsey St James's Chapel
Results.Summary: A pretty thatched 13th century chapel with lancet windows.

Results.Title: London Wall
Results.Summary: This is the best-preserved remnant of the Roman wall which once formed part of the eastern defences of Roman Londinium.

Results.Title: Longthorpe Tower
Results.Summary: Longthorpe Tower displays one of the most complete and important sets of 14th century domestic wall paintings in northern Europe.

Results.Title: Longtown Castle
Results.Summary: A powerful thick-walled round keep of c.1150 on a large earthen mound within a stone-walled bailey. Set in the beautiful Olchon valley, with magnificent views of the Black Mountains.

Results.Title: Ludgershall Castle and Cross
Results.Summary: The ruins and earthworks of a royal castle dating mainly from the 12th and 13th centuries, frequently used as a hunting lodge. The remains of the medieval cross stand in the centre of the village.

Results.Title: Lullingstone Roman Villa
Results.Summary: Luxury living in Roman Britain
Results.ImageAlt: The visitor centre at Lullingstone Roman Villa

Results.Title: Lulworth Castle
Results.Summary: A striking Jacobean hunting lodge on the Dorset coast.

Results.Title: Lyddington Bede House
Results.Summary: Discover how poor men and women from the past lived in a picturesque historic almshouse

Results.Title: Lydford Castle and Saxon Town
Results.Summary: Beautifully sited on the fringe of Dartmoor, Lydford boasts three defensive features. Near the centre is a 13th-century tower on a mound, built as a prison.

Results.Title: Maiden Castle
Results.Summary: Among the largest and most complex of Iron Age hillforts in Europe, Maiden Castle’s huge multiple ramparts enclose an area the size of 50 football pitches and once protected hundreds of residents.

Results.Title: Maison Dieu
Results.Summary: Originating as a 13th-century wayside hospital, this flint and timber-framed building now displays Roman artefacts from nearby sites.

Results.Title: Marble Hill
Results.Summary: Marble Hill is the last complete survivor of the elegant villas and gardens which bordered the Thames between Richmond and Hampton Court in the 18th century.

Results.Title: Marmion Tower
Results.Summary: The fine 15th-century gatehouse of a vanished riverside manor house, with a beautiful oriel window. The monuments of the manor's Marmion family owners grace the adjacent church.

Results.Title: Mattersey Priory
Results.Summary: The remains, mainly the 13th century refectory and kitchen, of a small monastery for just six Gilbertine canons - the only wholly English monastic order.

Results.Title: Mayburgh Henge
Results.Summary: A large and impressive Neolithic henge, much better preserved than neighbouring King Arthur's Round Table.

Results.Title: Meare Fish House
Results.Summary: The only surviving monastic fishery building in England, this housed the Abbot of Glastonbury's water bailiff and provided facilities for fish-salting and drying.

Results.Title: Medieval Merchant's House
Results.Summary: Step into the recreated world of a medieval merchant

Results.Title: Merrivale Prehistoric Settlement
Results.Summary: The group of monuments at Merrivale is one of the finest on Dartmoor: side by side here are the remains of a Bronze Age settlement and a complex of ritual sites.

Results.Title: Middleham Castle
Results.Summary: The mighty remains of Richard III’s northern power base.
Results.ImageAlt: The ruins of Middleham Castle

Results.Title: Milton Chantry
Results.Summary: Milton Chantry is all that remains of a 14th-century hospital later used in turn as a public house, a Georgian barracks, and Second World War gas decontamination chamber.

Results.Title: Minster Lovell Hall and Dovecote
Results.Summary: The extensive and picturesque ruins of a 15th century riverside manor house, including a fine hall, south-west tower, and complete dovecote nearby. The home of Richard III's henchman Lord Lovell.

Results.Title: Mistley Towers
Results.Summary: Two porticoed Classical towers, which stood at each end of a grandiose but highly unconventional Georgian church, designed by Robert Adam in 1776.

Results.Title: Mitchell's Fold Stone Circle
Results.Summary: A Bronze Age stone circle, the focus of many legends, set in dramatic moorland on Stapeley Hill. It once consisted of some 30 stones, 15 of which are still visible.

Results.Title: Monk Bretton Priory
Results.Summary: The substantial ruins of a Cluniac monastery, with an unusually well-marked ground plan, an almost complete west range and a 15th-century gatehouse.

Results.Title: Moreton Corbet Castle
Results.Summary: The ruins of the medieval castle and Tudor manor house of the Corbets are dominated by the theatrical shell of an ambitious Elizabethan mansion wing in Italianate style.

Results.Title: Moulton Packhorse Bridge
Results.Summary: A pretty four-arched late medieval bridge, spanning the River Kennett on the old route from Cambridge to Bury St Edmunds.

Results.Title: Mount Grace Priory, House and Gardens
Results.Summary: Glorious arts and crafts gardens combined with unusual monastic ruins and a manor house
Results.ImageAlt: Mount Grace Priory with its stunning gardens in the foreground

Results.Title: Muchelney Abbey
Results.Summary: Abbots’ luxury living on the Somerset Levels
Results.ImageAlt: The exterior of Muchelney Abbey

Results.Title: Netheravon Dovecote
Results.Summary: Charming and elegant 18th century brick dovecote, still with most of its 700 or more nesting boxes intact. Set in peaceful surroundings. External viewing only.

Results.Title: Netley Abbey
Results.Summary: The most complete surviving Cistercian monastery in southern England, with almost all the walls of its 13th-century church still standing, along with many monastic buildings.

Results.Title: Nine Ladies Stone Circle
Results.Summary: A small early Bronze Age stone circle of (actually) ten stones. Believed to be nine ladies turned to stone as a penalty for dancing on Sunday.

Results.Title: Norham Castle
Results.Summary: Commanding a vital ford over the River Tweed, Norham was one of the strongest of the border castles, and the most often attacked by the Scots.

Results.Title: North Elmham Chapel
Results.Summary: A place with an unusual story, told by graphic panels. The small Norman chapel here stood on the site of an earlier timber church, probably the Saxon cathedral of East Anglia.

Results.Title: North Hinksey Conduit House
Results.Summary: Roofed conduit for Oxford's first water mains, constructed during the early 17th century.

Results.Title: North Leigh Roman Villa
Results.Summary: The remains of a large, well built Roman courtyard villa. The most important feature is a nearly complete mosaic tile floor, patterned in reds and browns.

Results.Title: Nunney Castle
Results.Summary: Picturesque moated castle built in the 1370s. Held for the King during the Civil War, falling to Parliamentarian cannon in 1645: the gun-damaged wall finally collapsing on Christmas Day 1910.

Results.Title: Nympsfield Long Barrow
Results.Summary: Large Neolithic burial mound with spectacular views over the Severn Valley. Built by earliest farming communities in the Cotswolds almost 5,000 years ago. Internal chambers are uncovered for viewing.

Results.Title: Odda's Chapel
Results.Summary: One of the most complete surviving Saxon churches in England, this chapel was built in 1056 by Earl Odda, and rediscovered in 1865 subsumed into a farmhouse. Nearby is the famous Saxon parish church.

Results.Title: Offa's Dyke
Results.Summary: An earthwork roughly following the Welsh/English boundary consisting of a ditch and rampart. Origins shrouded in mystery but possibly built in response to events involving the Princes of Powys.

Results.Title: Okehampton Castle
Results.Summary: One of Devon’s biggest and most picturesque castle
Results.ImageAlt: The exterior of Okehampton Castle

Results.Title: Old Blockhouse
Results.Summary: Substantial remains of a small 16th century gun tower protecting Old Grimsby harbour, vigorously defended during the Civil War.

Results.Title: Old Gorhambury House
Results.Summary: The remains of a once immense mansion built in 1563-8 by Sir Nicholas Bacon, Queen Elizabeth’s Lord Keeper and visited by the queen on at least four occasions.

Results.Title: Old Oswestry Hillfort
Results.Summary: The huge hillfort at Old Oswestry was probably the stronghold and principal settlement of an Iron Age tribe, with its 40 acres protected by formidable ramparts.

Results.Title: Old Sarum
Results.Summary: Explore a vanished city

Results.Title: Old Soar Manor
Results.Summary: A small but complete portion of a stone manor house built about 1290. The first floor 'solar' private chamber, with attendant chapel and garderobe, stands over a vaulted undercroft.

Results.Title: Old Wardour Castle
Results.Summary: Showpiece house to romantic ruin
Results.ImageAlt: Exterior view of Old Wardour castle ruins

Results.Title: Orford Castle
Results.Summary: A fresh view of an ancient castle keep.
Results.ImageAlt: Photo of Orford Castle on a grassy hillock on a sunny day

Results.Title: Osborne
Results.Summary: Queen Victoria and Prince Albert’s beloved seaside palace
Results.ImageAlt: A view from the roof of Osborne, looking down at the terraces

Results.Title: Over Bridge
Results.Summary: A single-arch stone bridge spanning the River Severn, built in 1825-30 by the great engineer Thomas Telford.

Results.Title: Pendennis Castle
Results.Summary: Adventures in hands-on history
Results.ImageAlt: An aerial view of Pendennis Castle keep

Results.Title: Penhallam Manor
Results.Summary: The low and grass-covered but complete ground-plan of a moated 13th-century manor house, in a delightful woodland setting.

Results.Title: Penrith Castle
Results.Summary: Penrith Castle was begun at the end of the 14th century by Ralph Neville, who played a key role in defending this area against the Scots.

Results.Title: Pevensey Castle
Results.Summary: From Roman fortress to Second World War defences

Results.Title: Peveril Castle
Results.Summary: Spectacular hilltop castle that’s well worth the climb.
Results.ImageAlt: The ruins of Peveril Castle

Results.Title: Pickering Castle
Results.Summary: A classic medieval castle ruin near the North York Moors
Results.ImageAlt: The ruins of Pickering Castle

Results.Title: Piel Castle
Results.Summary: The impressive ruins of a 14th-century castle with a massive keep, inner and outer baileys, and towered curtain walls still standing.

Results.Title: Piercebridge Roman Bridge
Results.Summary: Stonework foundations, now marooned in a field, of a bridge which once led to Piercebridge Roman Fort.

Results.Title: Pike Hill Signal Tower - Hadrian's Wall
Results.Summary: The remains of one of a network of signal towers predating Hadrian's Wall, Pike Hill was later joined to the Wall at an angle of 45 degrees.

Results.Title: Planetrees Roman Wall - Hadrian's Wall
Results.Summary: A 35-metre length of narrow Wall on broad foundations, reflecting a change of policy during construction concerning the thickness of the wall.

Results.Title: Poltross Burn Milecastle - Hadrian's Wall
Results.Summary: One of the best-preserved milecastles on Hadrian's Wall, Poltross includes an oven, a stair to the rampart walk, and the remains of its north gateway.

Results.Title: Portchester Castle
Results.Summary: From Roman fortress and medieval castle to Napoleonic prisoner of war camp
Results.ImageAlt: Portchester Castle keep viewed from the adjacent church

Results.Title: Porth Hellick Down Burial Chamber
Results.Summary: A large and imposing Scillonian Bronze Age entrance grave, with kerb, inner passage and burial chamber all clearly visible.

Results.Title: Portland Castle
Results.Summary: Watching over a harbour full of history.

Results.Title: Prior's Hall Barn
Results.Summary: One of the finest surviving medieval barns in eastern England, tree-ring dated to the mid 15th century, with a breathtaking aisled interior and crown post roof, the product of some 400 oaks.

Results.Title: Prudhoe Castle
Results.Summary: The only Northumberland fortress never taken by the Scots
Results.ImageAlt: The exterior of Prudhoe Castle

Results.Title: Ranger's House - The Wernher Collection
Results.Summary: Discover a diamond magnate’s fabulous jewels
Results.ImageAlt: The garden at  the rear of Rangers House

Results.Title: Ravenglass Roman Bath House
Results.Summary: The remains of the bath house of Ravenglass Roman Fort, established around AD 130, are among the tallest Roman structures surviving in northern Britain: the walls stand almost 4 metres high.

Results.Title: Reculver Towers and Roman Fort
Results.Summary: An imposing landmark, the twin 12th-century towers of the ruined church stand amid the remains of an important Roman 'Saxon Shore' fort and a Saxon monastery.

Results.Title: Restormel Castle
Results.Summary: Cornwall’s classic circular castle.

Results.Title: Richborough Roman Fort and Amphitheatre
Results.Summary: The most significant Roman site in Britain.
Results.ImageAlt: Photo of an adult and two children looking out over Richborough Roman Fort and Amphitheatre on a sunny day

Results.Title: Richmond Castle
Results.Summary: A vast castle with well-told tales
Results.ImageAlt: Richmond Castle viewed from below

Results.Title: Rievaulx Abbey
Results.Summary: England’s most majestic and complete abbey ruins in a lovely wooded valley.
Results.ImageAlt: A dramatic view inside the ruins of Rievaulx Abbey

Results.Title: Roche Abbey
Results.Summary: Extensive remains of a small Cistercian abbey in a dramatic valley

Results.Title: Rochester Castle
Results.Summary: Strategically placed astride the London Road, guarding an important crossing of the River Medway, this imposing fortress has a complex history of destruction and rebuilding.

Results.Title: Rollright Stones
Results.Summary: Traditionally a monarch and his courtiers petrified by a witch, the Rollright Stones consist of three groups: the King's Men stone circle; the Whispering Knights burial chamber; and the single King Stone. They span nearly 2,000 years of Neolithic and Bronze Age development.

Results.Title: Roman Wall of St Albans
Results.Summary: A section of the two-mile long wall built between AD 265 and 270 to defend the Roman city of Verulamium: including the foundations of towers and the London Gate.

Results.Title: Rotherwas Chapel
Results.Summary: Family chapel of the Bodenham family. The originally simple medieval building has a fine Elizabethan timber roof, 18th century tower and striking Victorian interior decoration and furnishings.

Results.Title: Royal Citadel, Plymouth
Results.Summary: A dramatic 17th-century fortress built to defend the coastline from the Dutch, and keep watch on a recently rebellious town. Still in use by the military today.

Results.Title: Royal Garrison Church, Portsmouth
Results.Summary: Royal Garrison Church was built in about 1212 as part of a hospital complex. Although the nave was badly damaged in a 1941 firebomb raid on Portsmouth, the chancel remains roofed and furnished.

Results.Title: Rufford Abbey
Results.Summary: The best-preserved remains of a Cistercian abbey west cloister range in England, dating mainly from about 1170. Incorporated into part of a 17th century and later mansion, set in Rufford Country Park.

Results.Title: Rushton Triangular Lodge
Results.Summary: One of England’s strangest buildings, packed with secret codes.

Results.Title: Sandbach Crosses
Results.Summary: The two massive Saxon stone crosses, elaborately carved with animals and Biblical scenes including the Nativity of Christ and the Crucifixion, dominate the cobbled market square of Sandbach.

Results.Title: Sawley Abbey
Results.Summary: The remains of a Cistercian abbey founded in 1148, set on the banks of the Ribble against a backdrop of dramatic hills.

Results.Title: Saxtead Green Post Mill
Results.Summary: Impressive windmill, back in action with a set of craftsman-built sails.
Results.ImageAlt: Saxstead Green Post Mill

Results.Title: Scarborough Castle
Results.Summary: Amazing coastal views, 3,000 years of history and a huge site to explore.
Results.ImageAlt: The steep slope leading to Scarborough Castle

Results.Title: Sewingshields Wall - Hadrian's Wall
Results.Summary: A length of Wall with milecastle remains, impressively sited along the Whin Sill, commanding fine views of many prehistoric and later earthworks to the north.

Results.Title: Shap Abbey
Results.Summary: The impressive full-height 15th-century tower and other remains of a remote abbey of Premonstratensian 'white canons'.

Results.Title: Sherborne Old Castle
Results.Summary: Follow in the footsteps of medieval bishops and besieged Cavaliers

Results.Title: Shrewsbury Flaxmill Maltings
Results.Summary: Visit Shrewsbury Flaxmill Maltings and discover the building that changed skylines across the world forever.
Results.ImageAlt: Exterior of Shrewsbury Flaxmill Maltings

Results.Title: Sibsey Trader Windmill
Results.Summary: Built in 1877, this restored six storey mill with complete gear, sails and fantail still works today.

Results.Title: Silbury Hill, Avebury
Results.Summary: The largest artificial mound in Europe and comparable in size to the Egyptian pyramids. Probably completed around 2400 BC, it apparently contains no burial and its purpose and significance remain unknown.

Results.Title: Silchester Roman City Walls and Amphitheatre
Results.Summary: Originally a tribal centre of the Iron Age Atrebates, Silchester became the large and important Roman town of Calleva Atrebatum.

Results.Title: Sir Bevil Grenville's Monument
Results.Summary: Erected to commemorate the heroism of a Royalist commander and his Cornish pikemen at the Battle of Lansdown, 1643, this monument marks the spot where he fell.

Results.Title: Skipsea Castle
Results.Summary: An impressive Norman motte and bailey castle, dating from before 1086 and among the first raised in Yorkshire, with the earthworks of an attendant fortified 'borough'.

Results.Title: Southwick Priory
Results.Summary: Remains of a wealthy Augustinian priory, originally founded at Portchester: once a famous place of pilgrimage. Only part of the refectory wall survives.

Results.Title: Spofforth Castle
Results.Summary: The ruined hall and chamber of a fortified manor house of the powerful Percy family, dating mainly from the 14th and 15th centuries. Its undercroft is cut into a rocky outcrop.

Results.Title: St Augustine's Abbey
Results.Summary: An outstanding landmark in English history.
Results.ImageAlt: St Augustine's Abbey with Canterbury Cathedral visible behind

Results.Title: St Augustine's Conduit House
Results.Summary: The Conduit House is part of the monastic waterworks which supplied nearby St Augustine's Abbey.

Results.Title: St Augustine's Cross
Results.Summary: This 19th-century cross of Saxon design marks what is traditionally thought to have been the site of St Augustine's landing on the shores of England in AD 597.

Results.Title: St Breock Downs Monolith
Results.Summary: Originally 5 metres (16 feet) high and weighing some 16.75 tonnes, this is Cornwall's largest and heaviest prehistoric monolith. It stands on the summit of St Breock Downs, offering wonderful views.

Results.Title: St Briavels Castle
Results.Summary: The fine twin-towered gatehouse, built by Edward I in 1292, once defended a crossbow bolt factory which used local iron. Once a prison, now a youth hostel in wonderful walking country.

Results.Title: St Catherine's Castle
Results.Summary: Discover perhaps what is Cornwall's smallest castle.

Results.Title: St Catherine's Oratory
Results.Summary: A tall medieval octagonal tower, allegedly a lighthouse, built here in 1328 as penance for stealing church property from a wrecked ship.

Results.Title: St John's Abbey Gate
Results.Summary: This pinnacled gatehouse, elaborately decorated in East Anglian 'flushwork', is the sole survivor of the wealthy Benedictine abbey of St John.

Results.Title: St John's Commandery
Results.Summary: The flint-walled 13th-century chapel and hall of a 'Commandery' of Knights Hospitallers, later converted into a farmhouse.

Results.Title: St Leonard's Tower
Results.Summary: An early and well-preserved example of a small free-standing Norman tower keep, surviving almost to its original height.

Results.Title: St Mary's Church, Kempley
Results.Summary: Delightful Norman church, displaying one of the most outstandingly complete and well preserved sets of medieval wall paintings in England, dating from the 12th and 14th centuries.

Results.Title: St Mary's Church, Studley Royal
Results.Summary: This magnificent High Victorian Anglican church was designed in the1870s by the flamboyant architect William Burges, and has been called his 'ecclesiastical masterpiece'.

Results.Title: St Mawes Castle
Results.Summary: Henry VIII’s best-preserved artillery fort.
Results.ImageAlt: Image: St Mawes Castle

Results.Title: St Olave's Priory
Results.Summary: The wonderfully complete 14th century brick-vaulted refectory undercroft - later a cottage occupied until 1902 - of a small Augustinian priory.

Results.Title: St Paul's Monastery, Jarrow
Results.Summary: The home of the Venerable Bede, chronicler of the beginnings of English Christianity, Jarrow has become one of the best-understood Anglo-Saxon monastic sites.

Results.Title: St Peter's Church, Barton-upon-Humber
Results.Summary: Meet the ancestors in fascinating displays inside a famous Anglo-Saxon church

Results.Title: Stanton Drew Circles and Cove
Results.Summary: Although this is the third largest complex of prehistoric standing stones in England, the three circles and three-stone ‘cove’ of Stanton Drew in Somerset are surprisingly little known. The Great Circle, 113 metres in diameter, is one of the largest stone circles in the country and has 26 surviving upright stones. Yet recent surveys have revealed that the circles and cove were just part of a much more elaborate and important ritual site than had previously been imagined.

Results.Title: Stanwick Iron Age Fortifications
Results.Summary: An excavated section, part cut into rock, of the ramparts of the huge Iron Age trading and power-centre of the Brigantes, the most important tribe in pre- Roman northern Britain.

Results.Title: Steeton Hall Gateway
Results.Summary: A fine example of a small, well preserved manorial gatehouse dating from the 14th century.

Results.Title: Stokesay Castle
Results.Summary: England’s finest – and most picturesque – medieval fortified manor house.
Results.ImageAlt: Image: Stokesay Castle

Results.Title: Stonehenge
Results.Summary: Walk in the footsteps of your Neolithic ancestors at Stonehenge – one of the wonders of the world and the best-known prehistoric monument in Europe.

Results.Title: Stoney Littleton Long Barrow
Results.Summary: One of the finest accessible examples of a Neolithic chambered tomb, with its multiple burial chambers open to view. Bring a torch and experience the burial chambers at first hand.

Results.Title: Stott Park Bobbin Mill
Results.Summary: Fully working Industrial Revolution mill in a lovely woodland setting
Results.ImageAlt: The exterior of Stott Park Bobbin Mill

Results.Title: Sutton Scarsdale Hall
Results.Summary: The imposing shell of a grandiose Georgian mansion built in 1724-29, with an immensely columned exterior. Roofless since 1919, when its interiors were dismantled and some exported to America.

Results.Title: Sutton Valence Castle
Results.Summary: The ruins of a small 12th-century Norman keep, with panoramic views over East Sussex and the Kentish Weald.

Results.Title: Tattershall College
Results.Summary: Remains of a grammar school for church choristers, founded in the mid-15th century by Ralph, Lord Cromwell, the builder of nearby Tattershall Castle (National Trust).

Results.Title: Temple Church
Results.Summary: The 'leaning tower' and walls of this large late medieval church survived bombing during the Second World War. The graveyard is now a peaceful public garden.

Results.Title: Temple Manor
Results.Summary: Part of a manor house of the Knights Templar, built in about 1240, with a fine first floor hall displaying traces of wall paintings.

Results.Title: The Cenotaph
Results.Summary: The Cenotaph is a national war memorial in London. Now in the care of English Heritage, it is the site of the National Service of Remembrance every November.

Results.Title: The Grange at Northington
Results.Summary: Set like a lakeside temple in a landscaped park, The Grange at Northington is the foremost example of the Greek Revival style in England.

Results.Title: The Nine Stones
Results.Summary: Now in a wooded glade, this small prehistoric circle of nine standing stones was constructed around 4,000 years ago and is surrounded by a mysterious air. Winterbourne Poor Lot Barrows are nearby.

Results.Title: The Sanctuary, Avebury
Results.Summary: Begun in about 3000 BC as a complex circle of timber posts, later replaced by stones. Its function is still mystifies: human bone finds with food remains point to elaborate death rites and ceremonies.

Results.Title: Thetford Priory
Results.Summary: The extensive remains of one of the most important East Anglian monasteries, the Cluniac Priory of Our Lady of Thetford and the burial place of the earls and dukes of Norfolk for 400 years.

Results.Title: Thetford Warren Lodge
Results.Summary: Thetford Warren Lodge was probably built c.1400 by the Prior of Thetford; this defensible lodge protected gamekeepers and hunting parties against armed poachers.

Results.Title: Thetford, Church of the Holy Sepulchre
Results.Summary: The only surviving remains in England of a priory of Canons of the Holy Sepulchre, who aided pilgrims to Christ's tomb: the ruined nave of their 14th-century church, later used as a barn.

Results.Title: Thornborough Henges
Results.Summary: Thornborough Henges: A unique cluster of Neolithic monuments - sometimes described as the ‘Stonehenge of the North’.

Results.Title: Thornton Abbey and Gatehouse
Results.Summary: Venture off the beaten track to admire the remains of Thornton Abbey.

Results.Title: Tilbury Fort
Results.Summary: London’s guardian from Tudor times to the Second World War.
Results.ImageAlt: The exterior of Tilbury Fort

Results.Title: Tintagel Castle
Results.Summary: Myth and history meet on the rugged Cornish coast.

Results.Title: Titchfield Abbey
Results.Summary: The ruins of a 13th century Premonstratensian abbey, later converted into a Tudor mansion. The church was rebuilt as a grand turreted gatehouse.

Results.Title: Totnes Castle
Results.Summary: Get great townscape views from this lofty Norman castle

Results.Title: Tregiffian Burial Chamber
Results.Summary: A Neolithic or early Bronze Age chambered tomb with an entrance passage, walled and roofed with stone slabs, leading into the central chamber.

Results.Title: Trethevy Quoit
Results.Summary: This well-preserved and impressive Neolithic 'dolmen' burial chamber stands 2.7 metres (8.9 ft) high. There are five standing stones, surmounted by a huge capstone.

Results.Title: Tynemouth Priory and Castle
Results.Summary: The guardian of the Tyne.

Results.Title: Uffington Castle - White Horse and Dragon Hill
Results.Summary: Three atmospheric sites lie along the Ridgeway. Uffington 'Castle' is a large Iron Age hillfort, Dragon Hill a natural mound associated in legend with St George.

Results.Title: Uley Long Barrow (Hetty Pegler's Tump)
Results.Summary: A partly reconstructed Neolithic chambered mound, 37 metres (120 ft) long, atmospherically sited overlooking the Severn Valley. 'Hetty Pegler' was its 17th century landowner.

Results.Title: Upnor Castle
Results.Summary: Set in tranquil grounds adjoining a riverside village, this rare example of an Elizabethan artillery fort was begun in 1559 and redeveloped in 1599-1601, to protect warships at Chatham dockyards.

Results.Title: Upper Plym Valley
Results.Summary: This extraordinary landscape encompasses some 300 Bronze Age and medieval sites, covering 15 square kilometres (6 square miles) of Dartmoor.

Results.Title: Wall Roman Site
Results.Summary: Wall was an important staging post on Watling Street, the Roman military road to North Wales. It provided overnight accommodation for travelling Roman officials and imperial messengers.

Results.Title: Walltown Crags - Hadrian's Wall
Results.Summary: One of the best places of all to see the Wall, dramatically snaking and diving along the crags of the Whin Sill.

Results.Title: Walmer Castle and Gardens
Results.Summary: Tudor fort-turned-country house, with award-winning gardens
Results.ImageAlt: Tulips blossoming in the gardens of Walmer Castle

Results.Title: Waltham Abbey Gatehouse and Bridge
Results.Summary: A fine 14th century gatehouse, bridge and other remains of the abbey refounded by Harold, last Saxon King of England.

Results.Title: Warkworth Castle
Results.Summary: One of the most formidable castles in northern England,
Results.ImageAlt: Image: Warkworth castle as seen through and archway

Results.Title: Warton Old Rectory
Results.Summary: A rare survival of a large 14th-century stone house with great hall and chambers. It served as a residence and courthouse for the wealthy and powerful rectors of Warton.

Results.Title: Waverley Abbey
Results.Summary: Fragments of the church and monastic buildings of the first Cistercian abbey in England, founded in 1128.

Results.Title: Wayland's Smithy
Results.Summary: A fine and atmospheric Neolithic chambered long barrow 2km (11/4 miles) along the Ridgeway from the Uffington White Horse: it was once believed to be the habitation of the Saxon smith-god Wayland.

Results.Title: Weeting Castle
Results.Summary: The ruins of a substantial early medieval moated manor house, built in local flint.

Results.Title: Wellington Arch
Results.Summary: Get great views from an iconic London landmark
Results.ImageAlt: The exterior of Wellington Arch

Results.Title: Wenlock Priory
Results.Summary: Decorative monastic ruins in tranquil gardens.

Results.Title: West Kennet Avenue, Avebury
Results.Summary: This ‘avenue’ originally of around 100 pairs of prehistoric standing stones, was raised to form a winding 1 1⁄2 mile ritual link between the pre-existing monuments of Avebury and The Sanctuary.

Results.Title: West Kennet Long Barrow, Avebury
Results.Summary: One of the largest and most impressive Neolithic chambered tombs in Britain. Built in around 3650 BC and used for a short time only, nearly 50 people were buried here before the chambers were blocked.

Results.Title: Western Heights, Dover
Results.Summary: A huge fortification begun during the Napoleonic Wars and completed in the 1860s, designed to protect Dover from French invasion. Only the moat can be visited.

Results.Title: Wetheral Priory Gatehouse
Results.Summary: Well-preserved 15th-century gatehouse, the sole survivor of a small Benedictine priory. A miniature 'pele-tower' containing two storeys of comfortable rooms, it later became a fortified vicarage.

Results.Title: Whalley Abbey Gatehouse
Results.Summary:
The 14th century gatehouse of the nearby Cistercian abbey, which was the second wealthiest monastery in Lancashire.

The first floor of the gatehouse was probably a chapel.

Results.Title: Wharram Percy Deserted Medieval Village
Results.Summary: The most famous and intensively studied of Britain's 3,000 or so deserted medieval villages, Wharram Percy occupies a remote but attractive site in a beautiful Wolds valley.

Results.Title: Wheeldale Roman Road
Results.Summary: A mile-long stretch of enigmatic ancient road - probably Roman but possibly later or earlier - amid wild and beautiful moorland, still with its hard core and drainage ditches.

Results.Title: Whitby Abbey
Results.Summary: Haunting Gothic ruins high above picturesque Whitby
Results.ImageAlt: An aerial view of Whitby Abbey ruins with the town and coast in the background

Results.Title: White Ladies Priory
Results.Summary: Ruins of the late 12th-century church of a small nunnery of ‘white ladies’ or Augustinian canonesses. Charles II hid nearby in 1651, before moving to Boscobel House.

Results.Title: Wigmore Castle
Results.Summary: One of the most important castles in the history of the Welsh Marches and major centre of power for over 500 years, hosting royalty on several occasions. Deliberately demolished during the Civil War.

Results.Title: Willowford Wall, Turrets and Bridge - Hadrian's Wall
Results.Summary: A fine 914 metre (2,999 feet) stretch of Wall, including two turrets and impressive bridge remains beside the River Irthing. Linked by a bridge to Birdoswald Roman Fort.

Results.Title: Winchester Palace
Results.Summary: Part of the great hall of Winchester Palace, built in the early 13th century as the London house of the Bishops of Winchester. Most of the palace was destroyed by fire in 1814.

Results.Title: Windmill Hill, Avebury
Results.Summary: Classic Neolithic causewayed enclosure, with three concentric but intermittent ditches. Large quantities of animal bones found here indicate feasting, animal trading or rituals, or perhaps all three.

Results.Title: Windmill Tump Long Barrow, Rodmarton
Results.Summary: A Neolithic chambered tomb with an enigmatic 'false entrance'. Opinions vary as to why this false entrance was built.

Results.Title: Wingfield Manor
Results.Summary: The vast and immensely impressive ruins of a palatial medieval manor house, with a huge undercrofted Great Hall and a defensible High Tower 22 metres (72 feet) tall.

Results.Title: Winshields Wall - Hadrian's Wall
Results.Summary: The highest point on the Wall, in rugged country with spectacular views.

Results.Title: Winterbourne Poor Lot Barrows
Results.Summary: A 'cemetery' of 44 Bronze Age burial mounds of varying types and sizes, straddling the A35 main road.

Results.Title: Witley Court and Gardens
Results.Summary: Enjoy a grand family adventure in Witley Court’s vast and varied country house estate.

Results.Title: Wolvesey Castle (Old Bishop's Palace)
Results.Summary: Wolvesey has been an important residence of the wealthy and powerful Bishops of Winchester since Anglo-Saxon times.

Results.Title: Woodhenge
Results.Summary: Dating from about 2500 BC, markers now replace rings of timber posts, which once possibly supported a ring-shaped building. Discovered in 1925 when rings of dark spots were noticed in a crop of wheat.

Results.Title: Wrest Park
Results.Summary: Ninety acres of spectacular historic gardens
Results.ImageAlt: The exterior of Wrest Park

Results.Title: Wroxeter Roman City
Results.Summary: Discover life in a lost Roman city

Results.Title: Yarmouth Castle
Results.Summary: Henry VIII’s last and most advanced coastal fort
Results.ImageAlt: The sign over the entrance to Yarmouth Castle

Results.Title: York Cold War Bunker
Results.Summary: Spine-chilling Cold War time-capsule.
